newsitem.title: KUWAIT: Kuwait investments earn record 20pct in '96 - paper.
newsitem.headline: Kuwait investments earn record 20pct in '96 - paper.

text.p: The Kuwait Investment Authority (KIA), the state investment arm, earned a record high 20 percent on its multi-billion dollar overseas assets in 1996, Finance Minister Nasser al-Rodhan said in remaks published on Monday.
"The results show...that record earnings of about 20 percent have been achieved," al-Qabas newspaper quoted Rodhan as saying.
"This is a percentage that may not be repeated in the future because it is, by all standards, high," he added without giving further details.
Rodhan has said the reserves, estimated at about $35 billion, earned nine percent in the 12 months to May 1995.
The reserves are meant to help fund the tiny Gulf state of 2.0 million people when its oil runs out some time in the next century.

Kuwait's reserves were estimated at about $100 billion before the 1991 Gulf War that ended Iraq's seven-month occupation. The government sold tens of billions of dollars worth of assets after Iraq's 1990 invasion to cover the costs of its liberation and those of oil sector repairs.
